poem:
**Drama Studio**

In the drama room, words take flight,  
where tongues untie and voices ignite.  
Lines are scripts but also wings,  
each dialogue a song it sings.  
Here, oral tales entwine and twine,  
in artful dance of prose and time.  
A stage where silence taps her feet,  
and spoken dreams uncoil, complete.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Oracy already exists in schools. Just look inside the drama studio Why is it that, in all of the recent discussion of oral literacy (Letters, 30 July; Editorial, 27 July; Simon Jenkins, 24 July), there appears to be no mention of the one subject that already exists that has speaking and listening at its very heart: drama? Of course, discussion, debates, rehearsed readings – all of the things that advocates of oral literacy cite –". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
